comment._content:
Bettina Idrone Dorothy Loftus was the daughter of Major John Edward Blake Loftus.2 She married Thomas Henry Grattan-Bellew, son of Sir Henry Christopher Grattan-Bellew, 3rd Bt. and Lady Sophia Maria Elizabeth Forbes, on 1 June 1933.1 She died on 10 March 1995.1
      From 1 June 1933, her married name became Grattan-Bellew.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Of course Mount Loftus and the entire estate was won by the Loftus family in card game at the original Loftus residence in Ireland the haunted Loftus Hall near Hook Head, Co Wexford. The games of cards was in 1752 and the owner, John Eaton, of Comwellian settler extraction, refused to quit the property. Reason is that he kept two prize fighters at Mount Loftus, one armed with a pike and the other with a blunderbuss, who never left his side so that he could not be served with the legal writ. The law has long been changed and gambling debts are unenforceable in law. You couldn’t make this stuff up.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: In my experience, winning a house in a game of cards is usually a cover for either money laundering or tax evasion.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Bettina Loftus of Mount Loftus, Goresbridge, Co. Kilkenny, is listed as arriving at London on 1st July 1932 on P&O's SS Narkunda, having sailed from Brisbane via Melbourne, Colombo, Bombay and Plymouth. Her profession is described as 'Home duties' and country of last permanent residence as 'I.F.S.' Built by Harland & Wolff 1920

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Must Read In her article contained in the Old Kilkenny Review. Bettina speaks with grat warmth about Sir Nicholas and she says: Here is one of his love stories. One day he was walking in the Barracks in Kilkenny when he saw one of his sergeants beating and abusing his wife. the wife was an extremely good looking woman but her husband did not seem to appreciate her properly. Sir Nicholas was touched. He had an eye for beauty and being a gallant, still more for beauty in istress. He bought the woman from her husband there and then and took her to Mount loftus, where he installed her in a houce called Whalebone Hall near the present walled garden and he was wont to say he was never so happy as when he was in the arms of his mistress with his favourite racer neighing in his box below.” I would be happy too... AND The most famous Sir Nick story is this one. He was going back to Mount Loftus one day when he met a hawker selling whip handles made from holly. Sir Nicholas spotted a young horse behind the hawker’s cart and he bought him for £5. The horse turned out to be the finerst race horse of hs day and was called Hollyhock (whip handle) He won 15 king’s plates. He was unbeatable in england and Ireland and is buried at Mount Loftus.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Irish Times on Friday, 2 June 1933:
MR. T. H. GRATTAN-BELLEW AND MISS B. I. D. LOFTUS. A large gathering of friends were present yesterday to witness the marriage of Mr. Thomas Henry Grattan-Bellew, second son of Sir Henry and Lady Sophie Grattan-Bellew, Tennehinch, Enniskerry, County Wicklow, and Miss Bettina Idrone Dorothy Loftus, eldest daughter of Major J. E. B. Loftus and the late Mrs. Pauline Mary Loftus, Mount Loftus, Goresbridge, County. Kilkenny. The ceremony was performed by the Most Rev. Dr. Cullen, Bishop of Kildare and Leighlin, and took place in Graiguenamanagh Abbey Church, County. Kilkenny. The bride, who was given away by her father, wore a gown of ivory ripple satin, fashioned on graceful, close-fitting lines; the full, gathered puffs and wide shoulder effect of the sleeves giving the required old-world effect to enhance the beauty of the family train of Brussels lace, which was mounted on chiffon and secured at the waist by a pearl girdle. Her tulle veil fell from a wreath of orange blossoms and pearls, and she carried a sheaf bouquet of lilies. Two little girls - Miss Teresa D'Arcy and Miss Deirdre Grattan-Bellew - dressed in sprigged organdie, acted as trainbearers, while the grown-up bridesmaids were: The Misses Patricia and Linda Loftus, sisters of the bride; Miss P. Stanley, Miss D. Bromley, Miss B. Markes, and Miss B. M. Sharpe. Their charming frocks of pale pink organdie were relieved by turquoise and pink ciré satin sashes. Wreaths of velvet rose petals to tone were worn on their heads, and they carried shower bouquets of pink roses, and wore coral and crystal necklets and buckle brooches, the gifts of the bridegroom. Captain J. Ross, the Irish Guards, fulfilled the duties of best man...
Article includes a vast list of "among the guests". At a scan, was interested to see Senator [Oliver] St. John Gogarty. Oh, and the catering by by Mrs. Lawlor and Sons, Naas (presumably of Lawlor's Hotel?)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: There is another shot in the archive, showing the bride and groom, with her father on her arm, and the lady on the extreme right of this shot by the groom, with a large moustachioed gentleman. The large older man in that other shot (and just out of this one) is then Sir Henry Christopher Grattan-Bellew, 3rd Bt.

Deirdre Maureen Grattan-Bellew was born on 21 March 1924.1 She is the daughter of Lt.-Col. Sir Charles Christopher Grattan-Bellew, 4th Bt. and Maureen Peyton Segrave.
She married Gerard Kiernan in 1946.
From 1946, her married name became Kiernan. She lived in 2003 at xx xxxxx xxxxx, Stillorgan, County Dublin, Ireland.

I hope she is still hale and hearty.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The OS 25" map show the old house in 1900, which was pulled down to make way for the current house in the photo, which was built in 1909. If you flip between the 25" and the top Street Map (beta) radio buttons, you can see Mount Loftus House jump 30 meters East!
